subject: Re: international quikscript
msgSnippet: ... up. ... members QS ... are ... much ... My personal feelings are that the use of a standard is dependent on the audience and the  formality of the
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, pgabhart <pgabhart@...> wrote:
>
> This issue seems to be a Hydra and a new head has once more sprung
up.
> Once again I will attempt lopping the head off. I have read
members' QS
> whose choice of vowels seem peculiar to me in certain words as they
are
> not the ones I would choose for that particular word.
>....
> I believe you are making a mountain out of a molehill here. It is
much
> simpler to simply let people spell words in the manner that seems
> natural to them.
>
> In favor of limited anarchy, I remain.
>
> Paige
>

My personal feelings are that the use of a standard is dependent on
the audience and the formality of the writing. For example, if I was
to write to a fellow Australian in an informal or semi-formal context
then I would use General Australian pronunciations (probably also
including rhoticism as a general rule) but if I am to write to someone
from another country than I should use some mutually accepted
international standard. Also if I was to write in a formal context
than some agreed upon standard should be used.
This is not that much different from the TO that I use today. For
example, in Australia we are aware of both British and American
spellings. Either may be used in informal contexts but for formal
writings within Australia the British conventions are the standard,
although if I was writing formally oversees to an American then it
would be acceptable to use American conventions.
Of course it is not only the spellings that change but the grammar and
vocabulary-- most speakers of any language in the world vary their
usage of their language according to the situation.

I plan to list spellings from RP, GA and GAu in my project not just an
international spelling.
